name: Marseille (Monte Cristo)
description: A fictional version of Marseille, central to the story of 'The Count of Monte Cristo'.

content.title: History
content.body: In the world of **The Count of Monte Cristo**, Marseille is depicted as the starting point of Edmond Dantès's journey. It's here that Dantès returns from his voyage, only to be unjustly imprisoned following a conspiracy against him.

content.title: Geography
content.body: Situated along the Mediterranean coast, the fictional version of Marseille is characterized by a bustling port, narrow streets, and vibrant marketplaces. It serves as a key location for trade and commerce in the narrative.

content.title: Notable Features
content.body:
- **Port of Marseille**: A central hub for seafaring and trade, crucial for the plot.
- **Dantès's Residence**: The home of Edmond Dantès before his imprisonment.
- **Phocéen Café**: A fictional café where several key discussions take place.

content.title: Story Significance
content.body: Marseille is where the plot begins and where several important characters are first introduced. It symbolizes both the starting point of Dantès's misfortune and the eventual site of his return.
